description: In October 2016 he had quietly been named a special envoy to the United States by the Philippine president, Rodrigo Duterte. Mr. Antonio was nearly finished building a $150 million tower in Manila’s financial district — a 57-story symbol of affluence and capitalism, which bluntly promotes itself with the slogan “Live Above the Rest.” And now his partner on the project, Donald J. Trump, had just been elected president of the United States.
headline: Potential Conflicts Around the Globe for Trump, the Businessman President
GSA's Trump Hotel Lease Debacle

description: Prior to Donald Trump's official bid for the White House, the Trump Organization secured a 60-year lease with the U.S. government to renovate a historic post office in Washington, D.C., into a luxury, mixed-use development. The arrangement presents ongoing concerns now that Donald Trump is the U.S. government's chief executive. His position as both landlord and tenant opens opportunities for self-dealing that could prioritize his business interests over government efficiency. Additionally, foreign dignitaries and business representatives may book hotel stays and events as a means of currying favor with the president. A contractual clause designed to avoid such conflicts of interest prevents any elected official from sharing or benefiting from the lease. Because Trump did not divest of his business interest upon taking office, he may be violating the contract. However, his interests as either landlord and tenant would not be served by terminating the lease.
headline: GSA's Trump Hotel Lease Debacle

description: According to Trump’s May 2016 Federal Election Commission filing, which provides a range of values for each of his stock holdings, he owns anywhere from $500,000 to $1 million worth of shares each in Citigroup, JP Morgan Chase , Wells Fargo, Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs -- in other words, five of the famous “big six” banks.
headline: Trump's Stock Portfolio: Big Oil, Big Banks And More Foreign Connections

description: While Trump repeatedly singled out Ford Motors for outsourcing American manufacturing jobs, according to Trump’s May 2016 Federal Election Commission filing, which provides a range of values for each of his stock holdings, he owns shares (worth up to $1 million) in the Detroit auto giant. Google, which Trump accused of suppressing negative Hillary Clinton news, is in his portfolio, as is Berkshire Hathaway, run by one of his fiercest critics, Warren Buffett. Though he tried to start a boycott against Apple AAPL +0.55% in February -- after the iPhone maker refused to help the Federal Bureau of Investigation break into one of the San Bernardino shooters’ phone -- Trump held onto his shares in the tech company, which were worth as much as $2 million in May.
headline: Trump's Stock Portfolio: Big Oil, Big Banks And More Foreign Connections

description: According to Trump’s May 2016 Federal Election Commission filing, which provides a range of values for each of his stock holdings, he owns shares in Google.
headline: Trump's Stock Portfolio: Big Oil, Big Banks And More Foreign Connections

headline: Trump's Stock Portfolio: Big Oil, Big Banks And More Foreign Connections

He also hold stakes in a variety of multinational oil companies like Shell, Chevron and Exxon Mobil.

description: The connections to the energy industry doesn't stop there. The climate-change skeptic owns shares in Phillips 66 PSX -1.26% - a joint venture partner in the controversial Dakota Access pipeline, where demonstrations are ongoing, and in Kinder Morgan, another pipeline giant facing resistance for its plans to connect the Canadian oil sands to Vancouver, British Columbia.
headline: Trump's Stock Portfolio: Big Oil, Big Banks And More Foreign Connections

description: The connections to the energy industry doesn't stop there. headline: Trump's Stock Portfolio: Big Oil, Big Banks And More Foreign Connections

description: Trump also has a small investment in Canadian energy company TransCanada, the developer of Keystone XL pipeline, which was rejected by President Barack Obama last year but supported by Trump.
headline: Trump's Stock Portfolio: Big Oil, Big Banks And More Foreign Connections

description: The populist billionaire has other Canadian holdings, including $500,000 to $1 million investments in the Bank of Nova Scotia and the Toronto Dominion Bank, and $1 million to $5 million worth of shares in the Royal Bank of Canada. Such investments add to the array of connections Trump already has with foreign entities - including nine figure debts owed to German lender Deutsche Bank and China’s state-controlled Bank of China.

description: Ladder Capital, a real estate investment firm that specializes in risky lending, has loaned at least $260 million to Donald Trump's businesses — including $160 million for the ground lease at 40 Wall Street and $100 million for Trump Tower. headline: Exclusive: Trump financier Ladder Capital explores sale - sources

description: Real estate tycoon (and now U.S. President) Donald Trump was the show's host for the first fourteen seasons. After he declared his candidacy for the presidency, NBC announced that actor and former California Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger would become the new host of The Celebrity Apprentice. In December 2016, MGM confirmed to Variety that Trump has retained his EP credit on the series. The larger issue for MGM, NBC, and the White House is the payment that Trump will receive for the series. It’s unclear what his per-episode fee is, but it is likely to be in the low five-figures, at minimum.
headline: Donald Trump to Remain Executive Producer on "Celebrity Apprentice" (EXCLUSIVE)

Where Did Trump's Foundation Donate Its Money? IRS Documents Reveal Surprising Answers
Where Did Trump's Foundation Donate Its Money? IRS Documents Reveal Surprising Answers

description: The Donald J. Trump Foundation gave away $10.9 million from 2001 to 2014, taking a scattershot approach to philanthropy with donations to more than 400 different charities, according to a Forbes analysis of 14 years of IRS documents. Among the notable recipients: the William J. Clinton Foundation, a state branch of the ACLU and a nonprofit run by the New York Times, which Trump routinely criticizes on Twitter. Only $2.8 million of that money came from Trump himself.
headline: Where Did Trump's Foundation Donate Its Money? IRS Documents Reveal Surprising Answers

description: An estimated 36% of the foundation’s money went to roughly 100 organizations promoting healthcare, the Forbes examination revealed. The Trump Foundation gave more than $465,000 to both the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute and Operation Smile, which offers free surgeries to children born with cleft palates in developing countries.
headline: Where Did Trump's Foundation Donate Its Money? IRS Documents Reveal Surprising Answers

headline: Where Did Trump's Foundation Donate Its Money? IRS Documents Reveal Surprising Answers

description: SoftBank Vision Fund, a technology investment vehicle that gets almost half of its $100 billion from the Saudi government's Public Investment Fund. The United Arab Emirates has put at least $15 billion into the Vision Fund through its sovereign wealth fund as well. In May 2018, Cadre, a real estate technology startup co-founded and partly owned by White House senior adviser Jared Kushner, is sought an investment of at least $100 million from the Fund.

description: Prior to Donald Trump's official bid for the White House, the Trump Organization secured a 60-year lease with the U.S. government to renovate a historic post office in Washington, D.C., into a luxury, mixed-use development. The arrangement presents ongoing concerns now that Donald Trump is the U.S. government's chief executive. His position as both landlord and tenant opens opportunities for self-dealing that could prioritize his business interests over government efficiency. Additionally, foreign dignitaries and business representatives may book hotel stays and events as a means of currying favor with the president. A contractual clause designed to avoid such conflicts of interest prevents any elected official from sharing or benefiting from the lease. Because Trump did not divest of his business interest upon taking office, he may be violating the contract. However, his interests as either landlord and tenant would not be served by terminating the lease.
headline: Tracking who is spending money at President Trump’s D.C. hotel

description: The Chinese government-owned company was awarded a $19.6 million contract for road and infrastructure work as part of the residential piece of Trump World Golf Club Dubai project called Akoya Oxygen, according to a news release dated Sunday. description: Trump Organization partner in Trump World Golf Club Dubai project.
headline: DAMAC awards infrastructure works contract at AKOYA Oxygen to CSCEC as construction spend tops AED 5.6 billion

description: The Chinese government-owned company was awarded a $19.6 million contract for road and infrastructure work as part of the residential piece of Trump World Golf Club Dubai project called Akoya Oxygen, according to a news release dated Sunday. CSCEC was awarded a $32 million contract to build a six-lane road in early 2017, just as President Donald Trump was inaugurated and it was hired in February to construct one of the buildings at a cost of $163 million.
headline: DAMAC awards infrastructure works contract at AKOYA Oxygen to CSCEC as construction spend tops AED 5.6 billion

description: The Trump Organization’s partner in a lavish Indonesian development project boasting a six-star hotel and golf course with President Trump’s name has brought on a new ally: a Chinese state-owned company. The Indonesian partner, the MNC Group, said it had struck a deal with an arm of Metallurgical Corporation of China, a state-owned construction company, to build a theme park next door to the planned Trump properties.
headline: Trump business dealings raise ‘serious concerns,’ ethics office says

conflict: Trump International Hotels Management D/B/A Trump Hotel Collection
headline: ALEXANDRIA OCASIO-CORTEZ SAYS DONALD TRUMP SHOULD BE IMPEACHED OVER EMOLUMENTS CLAUSE VIOLATIONS FROM DAY ONE OF HIS PRESIDENCY

description: Prior to Donald Trump's official bid for the White House, the Trump Organization secured a 60-year lease with the U.S. government to renovate a historic post office in Washington, D.C., into a luxury, mixed-use development. The arrangement presents ongoing concerns now that Donald Trump is the U.S. government's chief executive. His position as both landlord and tenant opens opportunities for self-dealing that could prioritize his business interests over government efficiency. Additionally, foreign dignitaries and business representatives may book hotel stays and events as a means of currying favor with the president. A contractual clause designed to avoid such conflicts of interest prevents any elected official from sharing or benefiting from the lease. Because Trump did not divest of his business interest upon taking office, he may be violating the contract. However, his interests as either landlord and tenant would not be served by terminating the lease.
headline: ALEXANDRIA OCASIO-CORTEZ SAYS DONALD TRUMP SHOULD BE IMPEACHED OVER EMOLUMENTS CLAUSE VIOLATIONS FROM DAY ONE OF HIS PRESIDENCY
